snippet: After officials said they would let seven Americans leave Egypt during a prosecution of nonprofit groups, there were signs of a political backlash.
abstract: Egyptian officials say that they will lift a travel ban barring seven Americans from leaving the country during the politically charged prosecution of four American-financed nonprofit groups, apparently resolving a crisis that threatened to break the 30-year alliance with Washington; in order for the defendants to leave the country, they will be required to pay large sums as bail, as high as $300,000 each, and pledge to return for their trial.

byline.original: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and STEVEN LEE MYERS
byline.contributor: David D. Kirkpatrick reported from Cairo, and Steven Lee Myers from Washington. Mayy El Sheikh contributed reporting from Cairo.

lead_paragraph: After officials said they would let seven Americans leave Egypt during a prosecution of nonprofit groups, there were signs of a political backlash.

headline.main: Egypt Says It Will Lift Travel Ban, Allowing American Defendants to Leave
headline.print_headline: Egypt Says It Will Lift Travel Ban, Allowing American Defendants to Leave
